How to Choose the Best Computers for Digital Art

When it comes to digital art, you will need a computer that can handle the workload. You want your computer to be fast enough so that you can create professional-quality artwork but also have enough memory and storage space for all of your projects on board. The following are the technical aspects to consider before buying a computer:

Display

You can find a lot of great displays on the market, but there are some things to consider. First, the display size will determine how big your images look and how much detail is visible. You can find sizes ranging from flat 21-inch displays to ultrawide 50-inch monitors for a more immersive experience, but it all comes down to personal preference. A larger monitor means you have a larger canvas to work with.

Next up is resolution. A higher resolution means more distinct lines appear on the screen, creating better visual clarity and allowing for finer details. Look for a monitor with at least Full HD resolution, but you can work with even more detail if it is 2K or 4K.

Another factor is the refresh rate. It refers to the times the screen refreshes every second to display a new image. Most monitors have a 60Hz refresh rate by default, but some monitors have refresh rates as high as 365Hz. The benefit of having a higher refresh rate is that it makes the experience much smoother, whether you are playing games, browsing, watching movies, or creating art.

Processor

The CPU is the brain of the computer, and it’s what makes your machine run. A more powerful CPU means that you can do more things at once. A good example of this is Adobe Illustrator. If you want to work on artwork with lots of layers and effects applied simultaneously, your computer will need a lot of processing power to run smoothly.

For creative purposes, you will need the latest mid-range processor, such as Intel’s i5 and AMD’s Ryzen 5, or high-end ones, such as Intel i7 or i9 and AMD Ryzen 7 or Ryzen 9. Apple’s M1 and M2 chips are some of the fastest on the market and are worth considering.

RAM

RAM is the short-term memory of your computer. It’s required for multitasking, so the more RAM you have, the more you can do at once. RAM is important if you want to play games, edit photos, or make art on your computer because it lets programs access data in their cache faster than usual. 

For creating digital art, you will need at least 8GB of RAM to run most apps required, but 16GB or higher RAM means you won’t have to upgrade your computer and increase the RAM anytime soon.

GPU

A graphics card is one of a PC’s main components responsible for rendering graphics. The number one thing to look at when buying a new computer or a graphics card is how much power it’ll need to run all of your favorite games and apps smoothly. 

An integrated chip should suffice for basic creative work such as drawing and photo editing. Still, you will need a dedicated graphics card for complex creative tasks such as 3D artwork and animations.

Storage

Storage is another key part of your computer, and choosing the right one is important. You’ll want to ensure enough space for your digital art projects and plenty of room for other files. That means choosing between an SSD, HDD, or a hybrid option that combines both. Regardless of your choice, look for at least 256GB of storage on the computer.

SSD (Solid-State Drive): These are fast, small drives that allow you to load programs quickly by storing them on flash memory instead of spinning platters inside the hard drive itself—which means using less power to read or write data than hard drives. The upside here is that SSDs require less room and are more durable but expensive.

HDD (Hard Disk Drive): These are slower and bulkier than their SSD counterparts which is why they aren’t so popular now, but the advantage of having an HDD over an SSD is that it is much cheaper.

Operating System

While both Windows and macOS are compatible with most creative apps such as Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator, Clip Studio Paint Pro, and Corel Paint; it is still important to choose which operating system suits your needs the best.

Windows: This is the most popular operating system for digital art. It’s easy to use, and many programs are available to help you get started. You will also find a greater variety of Windows computers than Macs.

Mac OS: If you already have a Mac and love using it, this is probably the best choice for your digital art needs. Most professionals prefer using Macs because of the all-around experience that few Windows computers can match.
